i Ridg iU ng< .0 listing Wows j Hydrographie Report for Xebrarkc « SURFACE WATER RESOURCES OF NEBRASKA Physical Characteristic*. Nebraska as a whole represents a mo less level plain carved in some places into a very rolling surface by the diff drainage systems. From a topographic standpoint the state is divided four regions. The largest of these is the loess region, which comprises than one-half of the state, lying in the southeast and extending to Colora the southwest. Comparatively unbroken by abrupt changes in elevatior streams cottonwoods, box-elders, species of ash and a few « are to be found, which extend small distances into th' The High Plains region, characterized by its ligh the western edges of the two regions just described. F surface is smooth, but in many portions rough lands This region like the Loess has had its level surface cut up the action of winds and water. The stream basins in this sectk to great depths, forming high bluffs and deep canyons. In this art found the highest altitudes in the state. The table land in the south* portion of Banner county rises to an elevation of 5,300 feet, while Pine in the northwestern part of the state in Sioux, Dawes and Sheridan and Wild Cat Range, which lies between the North Platte and Pumpkin valleys, are other instances of the high altitudes in the state. The latter is a spur terminating in Wild Cat and Hog Back mountains, which a and 5,082 feet in height respectively The vegetation is somewhat similar to the Sand Hill region, con; of several kinds of low grasses,' the small cactus and various shrubs. W and cottonwoods are found along the streams while pines and cedars a on the ridges portion of the state is characterized by its broad gently sloping plains wi- ttily ~aii" occasional knoll or depression. There is, however, in many portior especially in the east, areas which have assumed a very hilly nature, the rest of years of erosion. Flood plains of very different character from the surroun ing country have been built up in various river basins. The soil in many places has been cut through and rock formations ha been uncovered. Drainage basins in the loess region are well denned at tributaries numerous. The Sand Hill region is not so well denned in extent and area as the Lo* region, but, with the exception of a few areas detached from,the main regie its general location lies across the central and west central portion of the sts from northeast to southwest. The topography of this region is characteriz bv shifting dunes of wind blown sands, but in many portions the surface h f *J ■ ■ » t .1 in i _ ' _ ' '- *. ' 1 J .^"'li.TT^.:i n« .: become grass grown and a more permanent nature given to the soil. Basi in dry valleys abound over a large portion of the region and some of these bei filled with water form many lakes and wet weather ponds. Unlike the draina basins in the Loess region, the tributaries in the Sand Hills are few in numl and banks of the streams are poorly defined. The vegetation of this section consists principally of various grasses the hard stem and hard leaf variety. Sharp yucca and the small cactus ; found in some portions. Shrubs, such as the wild rose, dog wood and gre; wood, and a small amount of sage brush, are widely scattered. Along the f

Conditions for m ing the now here, which have never been the best, were mad worse by certain improvements on the south bank and thereuj: station was moved to the railroad bndge where gagings are m present from the lower chord of the bndge. Passing trai interfere with the work. Records Available. From October 13, 1894 to Septembc Drainage Area. 13,540 square mile Gage. The channel is comparatively straight at ments are made but curves at a short dista: bridge. It is probably the ex test exampl in the state. Accuracy. 238 Hydrographie Report for Nebrcuka ELKHORN AT ARLINGTON Location. ! One mile south of Arlington in Section 13, Township ■ Range 9 East, on the bridge just below the Chicago' &Nort Railroad Bridge. N W Records Available. From April 28, 1899 to November 21* 1903 July 9, 1913 to September 30, 1914. RGace. On the original station an inclined gage was located two hu down stream from the highway^ bridge on the right bank, was washed out on May 10, 1899, and on May 29 of the sa similar gage was installed twenty-five feet further up stre datum was not changed. This gage was used until the cl< season of 1903. When the station was re-established in 191 was painted in black and white on the south side of the east i highway bridge. Bench Marks. During the first period the station was mainu bench marks were established. No 1. A spike in a pile, on and fifty feet down stream from tht bridge on the right ban tion 6.36 feet above zero of the gage. No. 2. A spike in hundred and forty feet down stream from the gage on the r and twenty feet from the waters edge. Elevation, 9.12 f zero of the gage. During the latter period a bench mark was t on the south west corner of the east abutment directly over Elevation, 15.00 feet above zero of the gage. Channel. Fine sand, rather shifting. Discharge Measurements. Made from bridge. Accuracy. High water gagings are affected by eddies from th bridge above, but in low water very good results are obtained.

Report Sebraska, 191 247 ■/ ph L ELKHORN RIVER AT WATERLOO 101th of the Union Pacific Railroad Station at ocatior Record* Available. From May 19, 1911 to July 19, 1913 ivere obtained by measuring from a point on the hand - ' center of the upstream side of the bridge to the surface 1 subtracting this distance from twenty feet. Gag Bench Marks. No. 1. Post with white cross painted on top ten feet south l the west end of the bridge. Elevation assumed one No. 2. White cross on tubular pier, up stream side and idge. Elevation, 99.68 feet. No. 3. Point from' which ade on the handrail. Elevation, 104.16 feet hannel. Shifting sand. 258 Hydrographie Report for Nebraska, 19 LITTLE BLUE AT FAIRBURY Location. At highway bridge one and one-half miles south of towr Records Available. From May 23, 1908 to September 30, 1914 Case. A standard chain and weight fastened to the downstream handra: ■ ' of the bridge in the first and second panels from the south end. Distanc from the end of weight to the marker, 19.53 feet. Bench Mark. No. 1. The point on the east edge of the cap of the east tub of the south pier. Elevation, 14.31 feet. No. 2. The east edge of th edge of the cap of the east tube of the north pier. Elevation, 16.53 No. 3. The heads of three nails driven in the east side of the telephon pole forty feet west of the bridge across the north channel. Elevation 12.46 feet. Bench mark datum equals zero of gage. Channel.' One channel at low water and two during high water. Sandy loar bed. . . Accuracy. It has been suspected that the power plant, which is abou mile above the gaging station, causes a fluctuation which might ren misleading results from the single gage height reading which has hi made each day. Two readings per day were made for a period of days which to a degree substantiate this suspicion but which h: w shown that no serious discrepancies have been the tion.

270 Hydrographie Report for > Nebraska, 191 i 'V .id •g' 1 i6 4 ,8: FRENCHMAN RIVER AT PALISADE Location. Just above the Burlington and Missouri river railroad bridgi Palisade. Records Available. From October 14, 1894 to September 28, 1896 Gage. The gage was an inclined staff on the right bank immediately at the railroad bridge. Bench Mark. The top of the second thread on the bottom of the east of the north pile of the second pier from the right end of the bri Elevation, 7.89 feet above zero of the gage. Channel. Shifting sand Accuracy. Reliable estimates of daily discharge can not be made by o ■ nary methods. During the season of 1896 special efforts were madi obtain sufficient data to afford reliable estimates of the daily discha: Two supplementary gages were installed and the observer was instruc to make frequent observations. The upstream gage was three hund and twenty-five feet above the main gage and the downstream gage tl hundred feet below the main gage. It was thus possible to obtain slope of the water surface at the time of making soundings and curr meter measurements, and the resulting estimates were fairly relia' The fall of the water table so obtained in a distance of six hundred ; twenty-five feet in a table follows. The gage heights are those obser on the main gage. Hydrographic Report for Nebraska, 191 ; 275 FRENCHMAN RIVER AT CULBERTSON Location. Just south of town at a pile bridge Records Available. From June 12, 1913 to September 30, 1914 Gage. A staff gage installed on the left bank of the stream about ten feet above the bridge. It is nailed to a frame anchored to the bank. Bench Mark. Three brass headed tacks on a stringer on the upstream side he bridge about midway across the stream. Elevation, 8.00 feet above zero of the gage Channel. Very shifting. For a short period during 1913 it was obstructed sod dam about two hundred feet above the bridge, but high water las washed this away Discharge Measurements. Made by, wading during low water about one ■ hundred feet above the bridge where the stream is in two channels, and during high water from the bridge which is at a very large angle from normal to the stream. Accuracy. Shifting sand has made the computation of daily discharge im- practicable Co-operation. Besides the co-operation of the U. S. G. S., the daily observa - tions at this station have been furnished by the McCook Irrigation and Water Power Company. Hydrographie Report for Nebraska, 19H 295 REPUBLICAN RIVER AT BOSTWICK Location. One mile south of town in Section 23, Township 1 North, Range 8 Wes Records Available. From June 26, 1904 to September 30, 1914. Previous 904 a gaging station was maintained at Superior, the data from ay be used in connection with the records of this station for V Drainage Area. 23,300 square mile: Gage. Regulation chain and weight fastened to the ; downstream . handrail. Distance from the end of weight to the index on the chain 20.52 feet. Bench Mark. No. 1. Top of bearing shoe, (cast iron) of upper chord of north span, down stream truss at north end of span. Shoe rests on i top of pier. Shoe has three openings, the east opening is the ark. Elevation, 15.75 feet. No. 2. The northeast cardinal oint of the rim or edge of the cover plate of pier at the south end of ime truss described above. Elevation, 15.89 feet. Bench mark datum the gage hannel. Straight for considerable distance above and below the section nsiderable size is a short distance below the bridge, Accuracy. Affected by shifting sand and shallow water at low stages.

308 Hydrographie Report for Nebraska REPUBLICAN RIVER AT SUPERIOR Location. At highway bridge two miles west of Superioi Township 1 North, Range 7 West. Records Available. From June 20, 1896 to November 30 latter date a station has been maintained at Bostwick and the records of the two statio: may be combined Drainage Area. 23,400 square miles. Cage. The original gage was a verti al staff spiked to piling feet above the dam with zero of gage the same elevation as the ere of the dam. Later an inclined staff was installed on the left the river twenty-five feet above the bridge. On Apri gages were installed, one a few feet above the danr mean elevation of the crest of the dam and the other in the r fifty yards below the intake Bench Marks. No. 1. A standarc located eighty-three feet north of the up stream and ten feet west of the line of the up stream tri vation, 4.92 feet above zero of the original gage and the gage a few feet above the dam; 6.92 feet above the race, and 4.88 feet above the zero of the inclined staff. N six inch by eight inch oak piling in direct line with crest of dar to the'east and fourteen feet east of the w wall and twenty-two feet slight an tree. Piling is one of a row of six and the fou Elevation, 9.07 feet above the zero of the origin Channel. On a slight curve. The bed is of shifting Accuracy. The conditions at this station were complicated b and race just below the gaging station and the result of th use the diversion dam as a measuring weir were compl intermittent use of flash boards and by leakage through t gage heights in the mill race were found to be no index to th arg because the flow was entirely controlled by. the mill half a rule Gage readings were therefore supplemented by noting the time reqi for a float to pass over a fifty foot range in midstream of the race. Measurements of discharge were made as before at the highway bridge above both the dam and mill race. The discharge of the mill race was also measured in order that the net amount flowing over the dam could be determined as a more stable relation between gage heights and the amount of water flowing at the dam was thereby obtained. The pro - cedure above outlined was continued during 1898. In 1899 and sub - sequent years, however the gage in the mill race was not read because when the mill was not working the channel of the race silted up so that the cross section area was slightly reduced. The depth of the watei was, however, noted at mid stream of the race and the ratio of such

352 Hydrographie Report Jot Nebraska, 191 y MISCELLANEOUS MEASUREMENTS OF WATER AND CONVEN IENT EQUIVALENTS A "second foot" is water flowing continuously at such a rate that one cubic foot passes a given pofnt in one second of time. An "acre foot" is water one foot deep covering one acre of land 1 acre foot equals 43,560 cubic feet, equals 325,851 U. S. gallons 1 second-foot will supply 1 acre foot in 12.1 hours. 1 U. S. gallon equals 231 cubic inches 1 cubic foot equals 7.48 U. S. gallons. 1 cubic foot of water weighs 1,000 ounces or 62.5 pounds avoirdupois. 1 U. S. gallon of water weighs 8.355 pounds avoirdupois. 1 horsepower is equivalent to raising 33,000 pounds one foot in one minute 1 second-foot falling 8.8 feet is equivalent to one theoretical horse-powei 20 per cent of the theoretical horsepower is generally allowed for the frictio: of machinery, etc., leaving 80 per cent for the net horsepower, therefore on second foot falling 1 1 feet equals one available horsepower (80 per rent effic iency). About 10 per cent of this is lost when converted into electrical energ> 1 horsepower equals 746 Watts equals .746 Kilowatt 1 volt ampere equals .0013405 horsepower. The approximate rate of flow of water in open channels ma, by observing the velocity of a float on the surface of the stream. T is greater at the surface and least along the bottom and sides, I retarded by friction. Careful experiments have shown cent of the maximum central surface six-tenths of the depth measured from that the mean vela velocity. The mea the surfaci The most approved formula for determining the flow of watt is Kutter'a: In this formula v — the mean velocity in feet per r — the hydraulic radius or mean depth in feet equals the area of cros section in square feet divided by the wetted perimeter or width along the bot torn and sides in feet. s - the slope; that is the fall of the surface in any distance divided b that distance.

This alue has been found to be .025 for ordinary irrigation canals and about one - alf this quantity for flumes of unplaned lumber. Nebraska, 191 355 Hm graphi Report TRAPEZOIDAL WEIRS <\s a result of experiments made in Italy, in 1886 by Cippoletti, he ted a • trapezoidal weir, the sides of which have an inclination of horizontal to one vertical. This is based on the theory that the a rectangular weir being less than its true contraction of the area if the weir be increased ■wing o its depth (since contraction increases in this ratio) lance the loss due in contraction, the flow through the emain the same as though the weir were rectangular without con- The conditions called for in placing a rectangular weir must be nearly ith a trapezoidal weir, but the distance of the sill of the weir from he canal must be at least three times the depth of the weir, at least three times the depth of the water flowing over o possess some excellent qualities, the chief difficulty >eing the same as arises in using the rectangular weir. where silt laden water is employed this may fill up above the front weir. This weir may be used as a divisor, and for fairness of lly adapted to use on irrigation canals
